One morning, When Gregor Samsa Woke From Troubled Dreams, He Ordered a Brochure Using Tourism Engine

One morning, when Gregor Samsa woke from troubled dreams, he found himself transformed in his bed into a horrible vermin. He lay on his armour-like back, and if he lifted his head a little he could see his brown belly, slightly domed and divided by arches into stiff sections. The bedding was hardly able to cover it and seemed ready to slide off any moment. His many legs, pitifully thin compared with the size of the rest of him, waved about helplessly as he looked.

""What's happened to me? "" he thought. It wasn't a dream. His room, a proper human room although a little too small, lay peacefully between its four familiar walls. A collection of textile samples lay spread out on the table - Samsa was a travelling salesman - and above it there hung a picture that he had recently cut out of an illustrated magazine and housed in a nice, gilded frame.
One morning, When Gregor Samsa Woke From Troubled Dreams

It showed a lady fitted out with a fur hat and fur boa who sat upright, raising a heavy fur muff that covered the whole of her lower arm towards the viewer. Gregor then turned to look out the window at the dull weather. Drops of rain could be heard hitting the pane, which made him feel quite sad. ""How about if I sleep a little bit longer and forget all this nonsense"", he thought, but that was something he was unable to do because he was used to sleeping on his right, and in his present state couldn't get into that position.

However hard he threw himself onto his right, he always rolled back to where he was. He must have tried it a hundred times, shut his eyes so that he wouldn't have to look at the floundering legs, and only stopped when he began to feel a mild, dull pain there that he had never felt before. ""Oh, God"", he thought, ""what a strenuous career it is that I've chosen! Travelling day in and day out. Doing business like this takes much more effort than doing your own business at home, and on top of that there's the curse of travelling, worries about making train connections, bad and irregular food, contact with different people all the time so that you can never get to know anyone or become friendly with them. It can all go to Hell! "" He felt a slight itch

Greetings from Alamosa Convention & Visitors Bureau!
Be sure to get a copy of our Visitor Guide to help in planning your stay in Alamosa or Join Our Enewsleetter!

Discover Alamosa and all it has to offer, from authentic local cuisine, to historic train rides through the Rocky Mountains. Home of the mystifying Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve, this vast outdoor playground is nestled between two mountain ranges, the San Juan Mountains and the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.

In the spring, the valley blossoms and wildlife flourishes. Join us during the annual Monte Vista Crane Festival when thousands of Sandhill cranes make their annual pit stop in the valley, or experience the art and culture of local valley artists during the annual Downtown Alamosa Artwalk.

Summer is an exceptional time to be outdoors in the valley. Take in the music, crafts and food at Summerfest on the Rio, share the adrenaline rush at the Alamosa Round-up Rodeo, or walk downtown to the Farmers Market for fresh local produce and more. Experience spectacular mountain views on the historic rails and machinery of the Rio Grande Scenic Railroad or the Cumbres & Toltec Scenic Railroad.

Fall and winter may bring lower temperatures, but not the end of activities. Cross-country ski, snowmobile or snowshoe through pristine powder and witness the spectacular nature that envelopes the San Luis Valley. Take a winter train ride and experience the magical beauty of our breathtaking snow-covered mountains.

Make Alamosa your basecamp, with 10 hotels & motels, more than 25 restaurants, downtown shopping, and a welcoming community. To learn more about Alamosa, request a guide, call us at 800-BLU-SKYS or explore our Virtual Visitor Guide.

99,Getting Warmer,"<table align=""center"" border=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" width=""660"">
Cold - Warmer - Getting Warmer - HOT, HOT!
Be sure to get a copy of our Visitor Guide to help in planning your stay in Alamosa!

Join us for the 6th Annual Ice Festival January 30-31. Sculptors will create ice art including interactive sculptures. Sponsors for the event will enjoy the Frozen Party Friday night. Saturday anyone can enjoy the fun with a Scavenger Hunt, 5K Run on the frozen Rio Grande River, Faux Snowman Building Contest, and the Fire & Ice Bonfire. Click for more information and schedule of events or call (719) 589-2105.
Cross Country Skiing, Snowshoeing, and Ice Skating

Winter in the San Luis Valley is beautiful and full of sunshine, so get outside and warm up with exercise! There are several spots in the valley that are ideal for both snowshoeing and cross country skiing. A couple of popular trails found just to the west side of the valley are the Big Meadows Ski Trail and Rock Creek Ski Trail. These spots are located in the Rio Grande National Forest and are groomed for outdoor recreation when there is enough snow. Cross country skiing is also allowed at the Great Sand Dunes Park and Preserve. Find trail info here, and pick up maps, supplies, and ski and snowshoe rentals at Kristi Mountain Sports.

The Ice Rink at Carroll Park is now open for skate rentals, refreshments, hockey, and public skating. Whether you need to practice your slap shot or triple Lutz, the Carroll Park Ice Rink is perfect for all ages and abilities. Visit www.alamosarec.org for more information.

Do you love an interesting and cozy neighborhood coffee shop with a wide choice of hot beverages, food, and Wi-Fi? Come in from the cold and warm up with the locals, a cup o joe, and a side of dough (or more!) at one of these fine Alamosa coffee houses:
 The Roast also serving libations at Main & San Juan just north of the San Luis Valley Brewery
 Blessed Brews in between City Market and Big R at Main & Market
 Starbucks inside the Safeway at Main & Cochetopa

102,Shake off the winter cobwebs,"
Summer is just around the corner, so now is a great time to start making vacation plans
Welcome to Alamosa!
Be sure to get a copy of our Visitor Guide to help in planning your stay in Alamosa!

Summer is just around the corner, so now is a great time to start making vacation plans. We can make your planning easier with the 2015 Alamosa Visitors Guide. This info-packed guide includes lodging and dining information, attractions, maps, and all the exciting events coming to Alamosa this summer. Whether you're looking for a quick weekend getaway or a family vacation they will never forget, Alamosa has the activities to make your trip memorable.

In late February, Sandhill Cranes make their annual journey from south to north stopping in the San Luis Valley. This year the 32nd Annual Monte Vista Crane Festival will be March 13-15, and will be educational as well as fascinating. There will be an arts & crafts fair, bus tours, and educational lectures at the Middle School by biologists & wildlife experts. So grab your camera, because this is one natural phenomenon you won't want to miss!

Hidden within the rugged terrain of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains is a 30 foot waterfall known as Zapata Falls. Witness its breathtaking beauty as water cascades from the rock crevice in the summer, or when it's frozen into a giant ice sculpture in the winter. It's one of Alamosa's most popular attractions, and it's free to visit. The falls won't be frozen much longer, so check it out before it melts away!

The Rio Grande Scenic Railroads most popular event, Rails & Ales,sells out earlier each year. This brew fest boasts over 60 beers from more than 25 different breweries to sample, plus tasty food and live music. And all this happens at the Fir Amphitheater sitting at 9,700 feet elevation. If you like beer sampling, BBQ, and live music, then buy your tickets now before they run out.

Chalk about fun! Alamosa's first-ever sidewalk chalk festival is coming to State Avenue on September 19. The Chalk-a-Walk is open to all ages and talent levels and will be fun for all! Come on down to chalk the town, or just mosey by for a chance to see the art. There will be crafts, fun activities, and food! Mark your calendar now so you don't miss this fun-filled new event.
For more information or official rules and registration, please email events@alamosa.org

Penitente Canyon is hidden in the low-browned volcanic foothills on the western side of the San Luis Valley. Long ago, Penitente Canyon served as a place of worship for Los Hermanos Penitente, or the Penitent Brothers in Spanish. The Brothersmen of deep faithpreferred to live secluded in the foothills and canyons of the San Juan and Sangre de Cristo Mountains.

12 Hours of Penitence is a new bike race at Penitente Canyon. The race consists of a 21 mile lap that gains less than 2,000 in elevation. Solo riders will achieve as many laps as they can within the 12 hour time limit. Duo and team riders will ride the course as a relay, having only one team member on the course at any given time.

It's Chili Season at the
Farmer's Market

Get on over to Alamosa Farmers Market at the corner of 6th and State Ave. (Eastbound Hwy. 160 across from The Colorado Welcome Center). You can visit the market Saturdays from 8 a.m. - 1p.m. through October 10. You can find fresh, local and regional produce, baked goods, crafts, cooking demos, live music and cultural events. And ... roasted green chilis, for heaven's sake!

Rio Grande
Scenic Railroad
Full Steam Ahead

See the Rockies on the longest and highest standard gauge railroad in Colorado! Depart from the historic Alamosa depot and travel over majestic LaVeta Pass to the mountain town of LaVeta to explore the quaint downtown before the return trip. Revel in the wildlife and natural beauty of the storied Southern Rockies. Come see why USA Today named them a Top Ten Ride.

Runs M-F, May 22-September 6
Departs Alamosa at 9:30 a.m.
Returns at 5:30 p.m.
First Class: Adult $99 | Child $89
A full season of concert trains starts June 13 with The Haunted Windchimes.
Visit colorado train for details and to order tickets.

Summerfest
on the Rio
Summer's First Festival

Summerfest on the Rio is an annual event that celebrates the San Luis Valleys eclectic arts and crafts community. Held along the winding Rio Grande on the first weekend in June, its our official kick-off to summertime in Alamosas picturesque Cole Park.

The park opens up Friday, June 5 at 4 p.m. There will be a concert starting at 6 p.m. with country artist Kinsey Sadler. Food vendors and the beer garden will be open. Saturday and Sunday are a big hit with families that include more than 125 vendors offering delicious food, fun entertainment for the kid in all of us, arts and crafts, and more. There is live music and a Poker Run on Saturday with proceeds going toward Art and Music Scholarships at Adams State University.

A' Camping
We Will Go!
And Hiking, Biking, Fishing ...

Dust off your tipis, tents, and backpacks and air out those sleeping bags. The San Luis Valley offers a plethora of unique camping opportunities to suit every taste. From the Sangre de Cristo to the San Juan Mountains, the jagged peaks and rushing rivers of the San Luis Valley public lands wrap themselves around this Rocky Mountain basin. Hit the beach at the Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve or hike to a remote location thats just for you. You will find it here. You will like it here.
There are countless ways to make lasting memories this summer in the San Luis Valley. Check out the calendar here.

Alamosa is an excellent central base to explore everything the San Luis Valley has to offer. The widest selection of hotels and restaurants, a hot springs pool, golf course, wildlife refuge, and the Rio Grande Scenic Railroad are right here in town. Alamosas central location makes it easy to choose a direction and get after it!
North: Saguache and the Saguache Mountain Range, Penitente Canyon, Creede, Crestone, Valley View and Joyful Journey Hot Springs, UFO tower, and gator farm.
South: La Jara, Manassa, Conejos and the Conejos River, Cumbres & Toltec Scenic Railroad, and Antonito.
East: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve, Sangre De Cristo Mountain Range, Zapata Falls, Fort Garland, and San Luis.
West: San Juan Mountains, Rio Grande National Forest, Monte Vista, Del Norte, and South Fork. Stop by the BLM office in Monte Vista or click here for bike and rock climbing trails.

Beat the Heat BBQ Challenge and Hogwaller Mud Run
July 31-August 1

There's no place better to spend a day on earth than the San Luis Valley in summer. Come join us for the San Luis Valley Beat the Heat BBQ, a sanctioned Kansas City Barbecue Society and Rocky Mountain Barbecue Association State Championship event. We'll have BBQ for eatin' and cold beer to wet your whistle. Friday evening there will be games, a beer garden, and live music. Live music and the beer garden run all day Saturday and there will be Peoples Choice BBQ for sampling, more games, family entertainment, and a pepper-eating contest.

Like any good BBQ competition, cookers will compete for prizes in chicken, pork, ribs, and brisket, along with dessert and Anything But categories, all judged by certified Kansas City BBQ Society judges. Competition BBQ is for judges only, but you can taste and vote for your favorite cooker in the People's Choice category. Even kids can get in on the action with the Kids-Q cook-off.
New this year at Beat the Heat BBQ

Saturday morning at 9 a.m. you can participate in the Hogwaller mud run obstacle course along the Rio Grande River. Mud is cool. So is Alamosa. Temps range from a low of 44 to high of 80 on average in the summer. The Hogwaller Mud Run allows you play like a pig so you can eat like one at the Beat the Heat BBQ!
For more information and to register, click here.

Sand Boarding
At Great Sand Dunes NP

For years, visitors at the Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve have been trying to sled down the dunes in plastic toboggans, rounded saucers, and even cardboard. It does not work at all. Adventuresome and creative people have developed boards specifically made for sand, featuring extra slick bases. These boards are the ideal tool for surfing down the dunes.

Sandboarding, sledding, and skiing are permitted anywhere on the dunefield away from vegetated areas. The park does not rent or sell sandboards, but they can be rented at Kristi Mountain Sports, 719-589-9759.

Whether it is shopping in Historic Downtown or taking in the sights and sound of the holidays, there is always adventure to be had in Alamosa.
There is no better way to experience the snow then to surround yourself in its fluffy goodness. The valley offers unique ways to experience the beautiful surroundings of the San Luis Valley.
After a long day of fun and excitement is there anything better than to just sit back and relax? Alamosa has a variety of choices when it comes to relaxing and dining.
Train to Christmas Town

The Train to Christmas Town is becoming an annual tradition in the San Luis Valley. It is an experience that can be enjoyed by all ages. A short ride on the train takes you on a magical journey. The little ones are submerged into the story and become a character in this winter wonderland tale. Rio Grande Scenic Rail Road

The ASU Adventure Club has a shuttle open to public that will take a trip to Wolf Creek Ski Area. They also offer rentals for winter activities, however these services are only offered up to the 18th of December.

Get a cup of joe or a seasonal latte and enjoy the surroundings from one of our many coffee houses. If the taste buds require something more distinctive try a cold glass of beer from a few of the microbreweries that the Valley has to offer.
Alamosa Parade of Lights
The parade of lights in Downtown Alamosa is a fun and inexpensive way to kick off the Holidays. From floats to tractors, all of downtown is lit up with twinkling bulbs and the sound of holiday cheer.
Have you done anything adventurous lately?

Kristi Mountain Sports, LLC has a variety of rentals from snowboards, skis, snowshoes and cross country skis. Take a hike into the snow packed Mountains or Ski across the Rio Grande. They offer a great opportunity to get out and try something new!

Enjoy a night cap to your adventures with a relaxing soak in one of the Valleys hot springs. The Sand Dunes Swimming Pool offers a year round greenhouse for adults with many temperature options that cater to the relaxers needs, along with the traditional hot pool for the family. Joyful Journey Hot Springs is well worth the travel for this spa retreat. The views are breathtaking and the experience is one of a kind.

Join us for the 7th Annual Rio Frio Ice Fest January 29-31. With the added event of the Rio Frio 5K on Ice last year, and the new Fremont Haunt Race and Slow Bike Race also both held on the frozen Rio Grande River, the Rio Frio Ice Fest is growing into a premier regional event.
     The most traditional part of the festival is watching professionals carve impressive ice sculptures along Main Street.  This years ice carving theme is STAR WARS!  And, the ever-popular Fire & Ice Bonfire will be held on Saturday evening in downtown Alamosa. Also, have a great time celebrating all of winters splendor with other activities like the Faux Snowman Building Contest, Kids Costume Contest, Scavenger Hunt and the Grub n Pub.  Click here for a schedule of events or call (719) 589-2105

The resolutions have been made, now its time to keep them. There is so much outdoor activity to keep you active and busy in the San Luis Valley.
     Alamosa offers a diverse selection of restaurants that cater to visitor's needs and wants. Find the meal that sticks to your resolution or explore what the taste buds desire.
     Don't stress the idea of going on vacation and not having a gym. Many of the lodging facilities in Alamosa come with fitness and pools to keep you on track with your goals!
     So make a resolution this year to try something new, go outside and experience the rush of adventure. Alamosa has the variety needed to be your adventurous destination!

Zapata Falls is an adventure any time of the year, a short hike and a splash in the water leads visitors to a majestic water fall in the summer. Come winter, make that same hike, stride over the ice and view a water fall frozen in time. If conditions are right, many have taken on the challenge of scaling the icy falls.
     Zapata Falls is a must to any itinerary, a short trip from Alamosa and open 24/7. It is located near the Great Sand Dunes National Park and is a must see attraction.
     Access Zapata Falls from Highway 150, 12 miles north of the intersection with highway 160.  Turn right at the sign and travel three miles on the dirt road to the parking area. Picnic tables and a well groomed trail await you.

The cold has moved in, but dont let that deter you from adventure. From snowmobile excursions to cross country skiing, adventure awaits!
     The San Juan Nordic Club will be hosting events and group activities this month! From snowshoeing to XC skiing, they do it all when it comes to winter activities. No experience needed to be a part of their adventure!
     Kristi Mountain Sports and Adams State Adventure Program are great resources for rentals and information on snowy explorations.

The San Luis Valley is a distinctive place that gives visitors a variety of benefits. The fresh mountain air and beautiful landscape makes ordinary activities extraordinary.
     There is something for everyone when it comes to adventure in the mountains. Whether it is climbing at one of the nation's highest altitudes or taking the family to that perfect sledding spot.
     Visit our site to get even more ideas for your next trip, and don't forget to bring that camera, San Luis Valley has some of the most photogenic opportunities in Colorado!

Come enjoy authentic western heritage at the Alamosa PRCA Round-Up Rodeo an Alamosa tradition for over 30 years. Have you ever seen a cattle drive? The rodeo parade on Saturday June 18th is led by real cowboys and cowgirls herding cattle just like the old days- but they are bringing them right down Main Street! Don't miss all the favorite rodeo events like bareback riding, steer wrestling, barrel racing, team roping and the all-time fan favorite, mutton bustin'! Rodeo events are June 21-26.

Check this off your bucket list - Sandboarding is that one adventure you don't want to pass up this summer! Ride the dunes at the Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve, home to the tallest sand dunes in North America.

Boards can be rented through Kristi Mountain Sports. They carry both sand sleds and sandboards specifically designed for sand. Just a beginner, or shredding the sand like a pro is no problem with either board style.
After a long day of adventure there is nothing better than kicking off those shoes, digging your toes in the grass and listening to some talented musicians.

The patriotic celebration starts with a Kiwanis pancake breakfast at 7:00 AM followed by the Main Street downtown parade at 10:00 AM. Then fireworks are at dusk in the Alamosa Fairgrounds.

This year marks the 14th annual Alamosa Artwalk. Enjoy live music, art, and restaurant specials in downtown Alamosa June 24 and 25. See local artists work and experience the heritage and culture of Alamosa and the San Luis Valley.
